title: We are ready for trade war if Brussels punishes us for Brexit, says Philip Hammond
text:
We are ready for trade war if Brussels punishes us for Brexit, says Philip Hammond We are ready for trade war if Brussels punishes us for Brexit, says Philip Hammond Britain could fight a trade war with the EU if hardliners in Brussels punish the country for leaving, Chancellor Philip Hammond warned yesterday. PUBLISHED: 21:59, Sun, Jan 15, 2017 | UPDATED: 22:29, Sun, Jan 15, 2017 GETTY Philip Hammond has warned the EU against punishing Britain for Brexit 
In a toughening of the UK’s position after weeks of threats from bitter EU leaders, Mr Hammond has said the Government will do “whatever we have to” and ensure Britain is competitive. 
“The British people are not going to lie down and say, too bad, we’ve been wounded,” he added. 
“We will change our model, and we will come back, and we will be competitively engaged.” Related articles Hammond hints at tax cuts to keep UK firms competitive after Brexit 
In an interview with a German newspaper, he made it clear that the UK will slash corporation tax among other measures which could see business flee from the failing eurozone. 
The significant intervention – fully backed last night by Downing Street – carries extra weight because Mr Hammond was previously seen as a Remainer. 
The attack follows threats from German Chancellor Angela Merkel, European Commission President Jean Claude Juncker and European Council president Donald Tusk. GETTY The Chancellor threatened to make the UK a tax haven to entice business from the Eurozone 
And, most recently, from Maltese prime minister Joseph Muscat, who chairs the EU for the next six months. The British people are not going to lie down and say, too bad, we’ve been wounded Chancellor, Philip Hammond 
Until the weekend the UK Government has kept a polite silence over the “punishment” threats. 
But Mr Hammond has made it clear that the UK is easily strong enough to take on the failing eurozone and win. 
He said that while he was “optimistic” a reciprocal deal on market access could be struck, he was not going to “lie down” and accept it if it was “closed off”. 10 things you didn’t know about Chancellor of the Exchequer, Philip Hammond Wed, November 23, 2016 Philip Hammond will deliver his Autumn Statement to MPs at the House of Commons detailing the government's spending and taxation plans today
